==Chinese==
{{zh-forms|alt=畜牲-less common}}

===Etymology===
{{zh-compound|畜|生|domestic animal, livestock|([[牲]]) domestic animal}} Variant: {{l|cmn|畜牲}}. First attested in ''{{w|Han Feizi (book)|Han Feizi}}'' (circa 2nd century BC). The expletive sense was attested in the ''{{w|Book of Sui}}'' (7th century AD). Influenced, through Buddhism, by Sanskrit {{m|sa|तिर्यग्योनि||animal creation}} and Pali {{m|pi|tiracchānayoni||the realm of the brute creation}} during the {{w|Six Dynasties}} times, as this word was used as a translation of the Sanskrit and Pali terms. Compare {{l|zh|牲畜}}.

==Japanese==
{{ja-kanjitab|ちく|しょう|yomi=on}}

===Etymology===
{{IPAchar|/tikusjau/}} → {{IPAchar|/t͡ɕikusjoː/}}

From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=ちくしょう}} {{m|zh|畜生}}, {{m|zh|畜牲|tr=trhjuw<sup>H</sup> sræng|lit=livestock + livestock; sacrificial animal}}, itself influenced by {{etyl|sa|ja|sort=ちくしょう}} {{m|sa|तिर्यग्योनि||animal creation}}.<ref>{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

===Pronunciation===
{{ja-pron|yomi=goon|ちくしょう|acc=3|acc_ref=DJR}}

===Noun===
{{ja-noun|ちくしょう|hhira=ちくしやう}}

# {{lb|ja|Buddhism|sort=ちくしょう}} [[beast]]: a generic term for animals, birds, fish and insects, as the reincarnated form of one who had bad karma in a previous life
# a derogative term for a person
